title: Federal Reserve Reverse Repo Facility: Drain Mechanics and Systemic Implications
summary: A mechanistic account of the Fed's overnight reverse repurchase facility (ON RRP) usage decline from $2.4T peak to near-zero, including primary dealer incentive structures and Treasury issuance timing.

EVID.rationale: Fed H.4.1 releases, FRBNY data, and primary dealer survey data cited directly.

MECH.rationale: Mechanism of RRP drain explained with T-bill issuance link and SOFR spread analysis.

INC.rationale: Primary dealer and MMF incentive structures quantified with rate differentials.

RISK.rationale: Systemic liquidity risk framed with reference to 2019 repo spike.

SPEC.rationale: Specific dates, volumes, and rates cited from FRBNY public data.

claims.text: ON RRP balances peaked at $2.553T on December 30, 2022 and fell below $100B by end of 2024.
Treasury bill yields rose above the ON RRP rate by ~20bps in mid-2023, incentivizing MMF rotation out of RRP.

source.title: FRED 3-Month T-Bill Secondary Rate
source.excerpt: 91-day T-Bill rate exceeded IORB by 18–23bps during June–August 2023.

claims.text: Total Treasury net issuance exceeded $2T in the 12 months following the June 2023 debt ceiling resolution.

source.title: TreasuryDirect Monthly Statement of Public Debt

claims.text: A rapid RRP drain to zero could tighten reserve conditions and reproduce 2019-style repo market stress.
claims.notes: Analytical inference from BIS and Fed staff working papers; not a stated Fed projection.
